comment._content: Again, definitely Hay Street. Law Chambers would be on the left of the photographer (but not when the photo was taken, of course!)

comment.author: 92609449@N04
comment._content: My theory on 'Flag St' is that the original was hand-written using a scrolled flourish on the first letter - H.   If this was written with two strokes, it well may appear to a non-West Australian as an 'Fl'.   Similarly, with a Victorian flourish, the last letter - y - could easily seem to be a 'g'.   These problems continually face the family historian, so I am familiar with having to look through a magnifying glass at old writing, even though I love that style.

comment.author: 33364206@N05
comment._content:
Possibility for the reference to Flag Street.  The Town Hall was the central office for telegraph communications and a flag would be raised from the tower when overseas or interstate mail had arrived.


 from hptrails.com.au   Perth Town Hall History
When the Perth Town Hall opened in 1870 it was described as “a place that symbolised the harmony of interests in the colony.” It was to be a meeting place of the citizens of Perth, a forum for Government of the city and discussion of matters important.

By 1924 the Council had outgrown the available space in the Town Hall. A proposal to demolish the hall and construct a five storey office building was met with spirited public protests and defeated. Instead, the Council moved to the Strelitz building on Murray Street. The Council offices and chambers were moved there the same year

comment._content: I have updated the description for this image and the others on Hay Street. Many thanks for your comments and feedback.
